Review:

Reflecting the film&#039;s Hawaiian setting, the soundtrack to Adam Sandler and Drew Barrymore&#039;s romantic comedy about short-term memory loss, 50 First Dates, features reggae-fied versions of new wave classics. While technically the songs should have been done with slack key guitars and ukuleles, the collection is a pretty fun mix of styles that haven&#039;t had much to do with each other since the heydays of Blondie, the Police, and Musical Youth. Only one of these groups is represented on the soundtrack ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â‚¬ï¿½ UB40&#039;s version of the Police&#039;s "Every Breath You Take," which is pleasant enough but not one of the more inspired pairings on the album. Likewise, Sugar Ray&#039;s Mark McGrath just isn&#039;t a strong enough vocal presence to carry off a natty dread version of the Psychedelic Furs&#039; "Ghost in You." However, Wyclef Jean and Eve&#039;s version of the Outfield&#039;s "Your Love" is surprisingly genuine, and while Wayne Wonder&#039;s version of "Hold Me Now" isn&#039;t as fresh as his own work, it&#039;s still a decent version of the song. 311&#039;s version of the Cure&#039;s "Love Song" manages to be faithful to the original and to the concept of the soundtrack, creating a new style ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â‚¬ï¿½ rasta-goth? ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â‚¬ï¿½ in the process. Robert Smith and company get another shoutout in the form of Dryden Mitchell&#039;s "Friday, I&#039;m in Love," which, unfortunately, isn&#039;t as successful as 311&#039;s homage. Somewhat predictably, most of the standout tracks on the collection come from the artists with the most reggae credibility; Ziggy Marley&#039;s version of the Cars&#039; "Drive" imbues the song with a little more soulfulness than most of the other songs here, while Elan Atias&#039; cover of Bryan Ferry&#039;s "Slave to Love" contrasts his raspy vocals with the smooth melody. Adam Sandler&#039;s closing track, "Forgetful Lucy," is one of his better and more restrained songs in a while; this song, along with the rest of the soundtrack, keeps the emphasis on "romantic" instead of comedy. Still, 50 First Dates is a fun and funny (if gimmicky) collection of love songs.
